javadoc:
Plugins are a basic building block in Ghidra, used to bundle features or capabilities into a unit that can be enabled or disabled by the user in their Tool.

Plugins expose their features or capabilities to users via menu items and buttons that the user can click on, and via "service" APIs that other Plugins can programmatically subscribe to, and via {@link PluginEvent}s that are broadcast.

Well formed Plugins:

  • Derive from Plugin (directly or indirectly).
  • Class name ends with "Plugin" and does not match any other Plugin, regardless of its location in the package tree.
  • Have a {@link PluginInfo @PluginInfo()} annotation.
  • Have a constructor with exactly 1 parameter: PluginTool.
    • public MyPlugin(PluginTool tool) { ... }
  • Usually overrides protected void init().

Class naming

All Plugin Classes MUST END IN "Plugin". If not, the ClassSearcher will not find them.

Some special Plugins marked with the {@link ProgramaticUseOnly} interface are manually created and do not follow this naming requirement.

Plugin Life cycle

  1. Your Plugin's constructor is called
    1. Plugin base class constructor is called.
      1. Services listed in the @PluginInfo annotation are automatically added to dependency list
    2. Your Plugin publishes any services listed in PluginInfo using {@link Plugin#registerServiceProvided(Class, Object) registerServiceProvided()}. (required)
    3. Create Actions (optional)
    4. Register {@link Options} with the {@link PluginTool#getOptions(String)}. (optional)
  2. Other Plugins are constructed, dependencies evaluated, etc.
    If your dependencies are not available (ie. not installed, threw an exception during their initialization, etc), your Plugin's {@link #dispose()} will be called and then your Plugin instance will be discarded.
  3. Your Plugin's {@link #init()} method is called (when its dependencies are met).
    1. Call {@link PluginTool#getService(Class)} to get service implementations. (the service class being requested should already be listed in the @PluginInfo)
    2. Create Actions (optional)
    3. Other initialization stuff.
  4. Your Plugin's {@link #readConfigState(SaveState)} is called.
  5. ...user uses Ghidra...
    • Your Plugin's {@link #processEvent(PluginEvent)} is called for events.
    • Your Plugin's Action's methods (ie. {@link DockingAction#actionPerformed(docking.ActionContext) actionPerformed}) are called.
    • Your Plugin's published service methods are called by other Plugins.
    • Your Plugin's listener methods are called.
  6. Plugin is unloaded due to shutdown of the Tool or being disabled by user
    1. Your Plugin's {@link #writeConfigState(SaveState)} is called - override this method to write configuration info into the Tool definition.
    2. Your Plugin's {@link #dispose()} is called - override this method to free any resources and perform any needed cleanup.
    3. Your Plugin's services and events are de-registered automatically.

Plugin Service dependency

All Plugins must be tagged with a {@link PluginInfo @PluginInfo(...)} annotation.

The annotation gives you the ability to declare a dependency on another Plugin via the {@link PluginInfo#servicesRequired() servicesRequired} / {@link PluginInfo#servicesUsed() servicesUsed}

Ghidra will ensure that your Plugin will not be {@link #init() initialized} until all of its required services are loaded successfully and are available for use when your Plugin calls the {@link PluginTool#getService(Class)} method.

Conversely, any services your Plugin advertises in @PluginInfo must be published via calls to {@link #registerServiceProvided(Class, Object) registerServiceProvided()} in your Plugin's constructor.

Cyclic dependencies are not allowed and will cause the Plugin management code to fail to load your Plugin. (ie. PluginA requires a service that PluginB provides, which requires a service that PluginA provides)

Plugin Service implementation

A Plugin may provide a service to other Plugins by advertising in its {@link PluginInfo} annotation that it {@link PluginInfo#servicesProvided() provides} an interface class.

Your Plugin can either directly implement the interface in your Plugin class:

  public class MyPlugin extends Plugin implements MyService {....}

or it may delegate the handling of the service interface to another object during its constructor:

  public MyPlugin(PluginTool tool) {
    ...
    MyService serviceObj = new MyService() { ... };
    registerServiceProvided(MyService.class, serviceObj);
  }

When your Plugin directly implements the advertised service interface, you should not call {@link #registerServiceProvided(Class, Object) registerServiceProvided} for that service interface.

Service interface classes are just normal java interface declarations and have no preconditions or other requirements to be used as a Plugin's advertised service interface.

Optionally, service interface classes can be marked with meta-data via a {@link ServiceInfo @ServiceInfo} annotation that can have a {@link ServiceInfo#defaultProvider() defaultProvider} property which specifies a Plugin's class (or classname) that should be auto-loaded to provide an implementation of the service interface when that service is required by some other Plugin. Without the defaultProvider information, dependent Plugins will fail to load unless the user manually loads a Plugin that provides the necessary interface service.

Multiple Plugins can implement the same service interface. Plugins that use that multi-implemented service will either receive a randomly picked instance if using {@link PluginTool#getService(Class)} or will receive all implementations if using {@link PluginTool#getServices(Class)}.

Plugin Events

  • Every type of plugin event should be represented by some class extending {@link PluginEvent}.
  • One PluginEvent subclass may be used for more than one event type as long as there's some natural grouping.

Component Providers

  • A plugin may supply a ComponentProvider that provides a visual component when the plugin is added to the tool.
  • TODO - needs more

Important interfaces Plugins often need to implement

  • {@link OptionsChangeListener} - to receive notification when a configuration option is changed by the user.
  • {@link FrontEndable} - marks this Plugin as being suitable for inclusion in the FrontEnd tool.
  • {@link FrontEndOnly} - marks this Plugin as FrontEnd only, not usable in CodeBrowser or other tools.
  • {@link ProgramaticUseOnly} - marks this Plugin as special and not for user configuration.
  • TODO

methods.name: <init>
methods.comment: Construct a new Plugin.

params.name: tool
params.comment: PluginTool that will host/contain this plugin.

methods.name: <init>
methods.comment:
Construct a new Plugin.
 
 Deprecated, use Plugin#Plugin(PluginTool) instead.

params.name: pluginName
params.comment: name of plugin - not used.

params.name: tool
params.comment: tool that will contain this plugin

methods.javadoc:
Auto-registers any services directly implemented by this Plugin instance (ie.
 the MyService in "class MyPlugin extends Plugin implements MyService { }" )
methods.name: registerPluginImplementedServices
methods.comment:
Auto-registers any services directly implemented by this Plugin instance (ie.
 the MyService in "class MyPlugin extends Plugin implements MyService { }" )

methods.javadoc: Auto-registers any PluginEvents listed in the Plugin's description.
methods.name: registerStaticEvents
methods.comment: Auto-registers any PluginEvents listed in the Plugin's description.

methods.name: getPluginName
methods.comment:
Returns plugin name or null if pluginClass does not extend Plugin.
 
 Deprecated, use PluginUtils#getPluginNameFromClass(Class)

methods.name: getName
methods.comment: Returns this plugin's name.

return.comment: String name, derived from simple class name.

methods.name: processEvent
methods.comment:
Method called to process a plugin event.  Plugins should override this method
 if the plugin processes PluginEvents;

params.name: event
params.comment: plugin to process

methods.javadoc:
Get the {@link PluginTool} that hosts/contains this plugin.
@return PluginTool
methods.name: getTool
methods.comment: Get the PluginTool that hosts/contains this plugin.

methods.name: getSupportedDataTypes
methods.comment: Return classes of data types that this plugin can support.

return.comment: classes of data types that this plugin can support

methods.name: acceptData
methods.comment: Method called if the plugin supports this domain file.

params.name: data
params.comment: array of DomainFiles

methods.name: getData
methods.comment: Get the domain files that this plugin has open.

return.comment: array of DomainFiles that are open by this Plugin.

methods.javadoc:
Called after the constructor and before {@link #init()} to publish services to the Tool's service registry.

Services registered during the constructor call will be queued in the services list. This method will register those early services with the Tool, and henceforth, new services will be directly registered with the Tool.
methods.name: initServices
methods.comment:
Called after the constructor and before #init() to publish services to 
 the Tool's service registry.
 
 Services registered during the constructor call will be queued in the services list.
 This method will register those early services with the Tool, and henceforth,
 new services will be directly registered with the Tool.

methods.javadoc:
Initialization method; override to add initialization for this plugin.
 This is where a plugin should acquire its services. When this method
 is called, all plugins have been instantiated in the tool.
methods.name: init
methods.comment:
Initialization method; override to add initialization for this plugin.
 This is where a plugin should acquire its services. When this method
 is called, all plugins have been instantiated in the tool.

methods.javadoc:
Tells a plugin that it is no longer needed.  The plugin should release
 any resources that it has.  All actions, components, services will automatically
 be cleaned up.
methods.name: dispose
methods.comment:
Tells a plugin that it is no longer needed.  The plugin should release
 any resources that it has.  All actions, components, services will automatically
 be cleaned up.

methods.name: readConfigState
methods.comment:
Tells the Plugin to read its data-independent (preferences)
 properties from the input stream.

params.name: saveState
params.comment: object that holds primitives for state information

methods.name: writeConfigState
methods.comment:
Tells a Plugin to write any data-independent (preferences)
 properties to the output stream.

params.name: saveState
params.comment: object that holds primitives for state information

methods.name: writeDataState
methods.comment:
Tells the Plugin to write any data-dependent state to the
 output stream.

params.name: saveState
params.comment: object that holds primitives for state information

methods.name: readDataState
methods.comment:
Tells the Plugin to read its data-dependent state from the
 given SaveState object.

params.name: saveState
params.comment: object that holds primitives for state information

methods.name: firePluginEvent
methods.comment:
Fire the given plugin event; the tool notifies all other plugins
 who are interested in receiving the given event type.

params.name: event
params.comment: event to fire

methods.name: serviceAdded
methods.comment:
Notifies this plugin that a service has been added to
   the plugin tool.
 Plugins should override this method if they update their state
 when a particular service is added.

params.name: interfaceClass
params.comment: The interface of the added service

params.name: service
params.comment: service that is being added

methods.name: serviceRemoved
methods.comment:
Notifies this plugin that service has been removed from the
   plugin tool.
 Plugins should override this method if they update their state
 when a particular service is removed.

params.name: interfaceClass
params.comment: The interface of the added service

params.name: service
params.comment: that is being removed.

methods.javadoc: Check if this plugin depends on the given plugin.
methods.name: dependsUpon
methods.comment: Check if this plugin depends on the given plugin.

methods.javadoc:
Checks if this plugin is missing a required service.
@return boolean true if a required service isn't available via the PluginTool.
methods.name: hasMissingRequiredService
methods.comment: Checks if this plugin is missing a required service.

return.comment: boolean true if a required service isn't available via the PluginTool.

methods.name: getList
methods.comment: Used to choose between lists to support the old Plugin ABI backward compatible lists

params.name: l1
params.comment: the new list from the static PluginDescription config - preferred if it has any elements

params.name: l2
params.comment: the old list - only returned if l1 is empty

return.comment: either l1 or l2, depending on which one has elements.

methods.javadoc:
Register event that this plugin produces.

Deprecated, use {@link PluginInfo @PluginInfo.eventsProduced} instead.

@param eventClass Class of the produced event; class is required to force it to be loaded
methods.name: registerEventProduced
methods.comment:
Register event that this plugin produces.
 
 Deprecated, use PluginInfo instead.

params.name: eventClass
params.comment:
Class of the produced event; class is required to force it
 to be loaded

methods.javadoc:
Register event that this plugin consumes.

Deprecated, use {@link PluginInfo @PluginInfo.eventsConsumed} instead.

@param eventClass Class for the event; class is required to force it to be loaded
methods.name: registerEventConsumed
methods.comment:
Register event that this plugin consumes.
 
 Deprecated, use PluginInfo instead.

params.name: eventClass
params.comment:
Class for the event; class is required to force it
 to be loaded

methods.javadoc:
Register event that this plugin consumes.

@param eventClass Class for the event; class is required to force it to be loaded
methods.name: registerDynamicEventConsumed
methods.comment: Register event that this plugin consumes.

params.name: eventClass
params.comment:
Class for the event; class is required to force it
 to be loaded

methods.javadoc:
Registers a service.

If the constructor isn't finished yet (constructorFinished == false), the service is just queued up in the services list.

If the constructor is finished, the service is added to the services list and registered with the PluginTool's services.

The {@link #initServices()} handles registering the services queued during the constructor.

@param interfaceClass Class that the service object implements. @param service Service object instance. @param dynamicRegister boolean flag that indicates that the service being registered is being registered during the 'static' initialization phase (using information from the static {@link PluginDescription}) or in a dynamic manner during runtime.
methods.name: doRegisterServiceProvided
methods.comment:
Registers a service.
 
 If the constructor isn't finished yet (constructorFinished == false), the service is
 just queued up in the services list.
 
 If the constructor is finished, the service is added to the services list and registered
 with the PluginTool's services.
 
 The #initServices() handles registering the services queued during the constructor.

params.name: interfaceClass
params.comment: Class that the service object implements.

params.name: service
params.comment: Service object instance.

params.name: dynamicRegister
params.comment:
boolean flag that indicates that the service being registered
 is being registered during the 'static' initialization phase (using information from
 the static PluginDescription) or in a dynamic manner during runtime.

methods.javadoc:
Used to register a service (that has already been announced in this Plugin's PluginInfo annotation via {@link PluginInfo#servicesProvided() servicesProvided = SomeService.class}) during the Plugin's constructor phase, IFF the service is implemented by an object other than the Plugin instance itself.

Do not use this to register a service if your Plugin class implements that service's interface because your Plugin will have been automatically registered as providing that service.

If you need to register a service after the constructor is finished, use {@link #registerDynamicServiceProvided(Class, Object)}.

Using this method outside of your constructor will (someday) throw an IllegalArgumentException. @param interfaceClass service interface class @param service service implementation
methods.name: registerServiceProvided
methods.comment:
Used to register a service (that has already been announced in this Plugin's
 PluginInfo annotation via
 PluginInfo#servicesProvided()) during the
 Plugin's constructor phase, IFF the service is implemented by an object other
 than the Plugin instance itself.
 
 Do not use this to register a service if your Plugin class implements that
 service's interface because your Plugin will have been automatically registered as
 providing that service.
 
 If you need to register a service after the constructor is finished, use
 #registerDynamicServiceProvided(Class, Object).
 
 Using this method outside of your constructor will (someday) throw an IllegalArgumentException.

params.name: interfaceClass
params.comment: service interface class

params.name: service
params.comment: service implementation

methods.name: registerDynamicServiceProvided
methods.comment:
Used to register a service dynamically, during runtime, instead of during the Plugin's
 constructor.

params.name: interfaceClass
params.comment: service interface class

params.name: service
params.comment: service implementation

methods.javadoc:
Returns the combination of required and non-required used services.
@return union of the lists of required and non-required used services.
methods.name: getServicesRequired
methods.comment: Returns the combination of required and non-required used services.

return.comment: union of the lists of required and non-required used services.

methods.name: registerServiceUsed
methods.comment:
Registers a dependency on a service interface Class.
 
 This method is deprecated.  Use PluginInfo#servicesRequired()
 instead.

params.name: interfaceClass
params.comment: interface class that this plugin depends on

params.name: isDependency
params.comment:
boolean flag, if true this plugin will not work without the
 specified service, if false this service can work without it.  If false, this
 method is a no-op as non-dependency registration information is now discarded.

methods.javadoc:
Called to force this plugin to terminate any tasks it has running and
 apply any unsaved data to domain objects or files. If it can't do
 this or the user cancels then this returns false.
@return true if this plugin can close.
methods.name: canClose
methods.comment:
Called to force this plugin to terminate any tasks it has running and
 apply any unsaved data to domain objects or files. If it can't do
 this or the user cancels then this returns false.

return.comment: true if this plugin can close.

methods.name: canCloseDomainObject
methods.comment:
Override this method if the plugin needs to cancel the closing of
 the domain object.

return.comment: false if the domain object should NOT be closed

methods.name: prepareToSave
methods.comment:
Called to allow this plugin to flush any caches to the domain object before it is
 saved.

params.name: dObj
params.comment: domain object about to be saved

methods.name: saveData
methods.comment: Called to force this plugin to save any domain object data it is controlling.

return.comment:
false if this plugin controls a domain object, but couldn't
 save its data or the user canceled the save.

methods.javadoc:
Returns true if this plugin has data that needs saving;
@return true if this plugin has data that needs saving;
methods.name: hasUnsaveData
methods.comment: Returns true if this plugin has data that needs saving;

return.comment: true if this plugin has data that needs saving;

methods.javadoc: Close the plugin.
methods.name: close
methods.comment: Close the plugin.

methods.javadoc:
Provides the transient state object that was returned in the corresponding getTransientState()
 call.  Plugins should override this method if they have state that needs to be saved as domain objects
 get switched between active and inactive.
@param state the state object that was generated by this plugin's getTransientState() method.
methods.name: restoreTransientState
methods.comment:
Provides the transient state object that was returned in the corresponding getTransientState()
 call.  Plugins should override this method if they have state that needs to be saved as domain objects
 get switched between active and inactive.

params.name: state
params.comment: the state object that was generated by this plugin's getTransientState() method.

methods.javadoc:
Returns an object containing the plugins state.  Plugins should override this method if
 they have state that they want to maintain between domain object state transitions (i.e. when the
 user tabs to a different domain object and back) Whatever object is returned will be fed back to
 the plugin after the tool state is switch back to the domain object that was active when the this
 method was called.
@return Object to be return in the restoreTransientState() method.
methods.name: getTransientState
methods.comment:
Returns an object containing the plugins state.  Plugins should override this method if
 they have state that they want to maintain between domain object state transitions (i.e. when the
 user tabs to a different domain object and back) Whatever object is returned will be fed back to
 the plugin after the tool state is switch back to the domain object that was active when the this
 method was called.

return.comment: Object to be return in the restoreTransientState() method.

methods.javadoc: Notification that all plugins have had their data states restored.
methods.name: dataStateRestoreCompleted
methods.comment: Notification that all plugins have had their data states restored.

methods.name: getUndoRedoState
methods.comment:
Returns an object containing the plugin's state as needed to restore itself after an undo
 or redo operation.  Plugins should override this method if they have special undo/redo handling.

params.name: domainObject
params.comment: the object that is about to or has had undoable changes made to it.

methods.name: restoreUndoRedoState
methods.comment:
Updates the plugin's state based on the data stored in the state object.  The state object
 is the object that was returned by this plugin in the #getUndoRedoState(DomainObject)

params.name: domainObject
params.comment: the domain object that has had an undo or redo operation applied to it.

params.name: state
params.comment: the state that was recorded before the undo or redo operation.

methods.javadoc:
Returns the static {@link PluginDescription} object that was derived from the {@link PluginInfo @PluginInfo} annotation at the top of your Plugin.

@return the static/shared {@link PluginDescription} instance that describes this Plugin.
methods.name: getPluginDescription
methods.comment:
Returns the static PluginDescription object that was derived from the
 PluginInfo annotation at the top of your Plugin.

return.comment: the static/shared PluginDescription instance that describes this Plugin.

name: Plugin
comment:
Plugins are a basic building block in Ghidra, used to bundle features or capabilities
 into a unit that can be enabled or disabled by the user in their Tool.
 
 Plugins expose their features or capabilities to users via menu items and buttons that
 the user can click on, and via "service" APIs that other Plugins can programmatically subscribe
 to, and via PluginEvents that are broadcast.
 
 Well formed Plugins:
 
 	Derive from Plugin (directly or indirectly).
 	Class name ends with "Plugin" and does not match any other Plugin, regardless of
 	its location in the package tree.
 	Have a PluginInfo annotation.
 	Have a constructor with exactly 1 parameter: PluginTool.
 		
  			public MyPlugin(PluginTool tool) { ... }
  		
  	Usually overrides protected void init().
 
 Class naming
 All Plugin Classes MUST END IN "Plugin".  If not, the ClassSearcher will not find them.
 
 Some special Plugins marked with the ProgramaticUseOnly interface are manually
 created and do not follow this naming requirement.

 Plugin Life cycle
 
 	Your Plugin's constructor is called
 		
 			Plugin base class constructor is called.
 				
 					Services listed in the @PluginInfo annotation are automatically added
 					to dependency list
 				
 			Your Plugin publishes any services listed in PluginInfo using
 			Plugin#registerServiceProvided(Class, Object).
 			(required)
  			Create Actions (optional)
  			Register Options with the PluginTool#getOptions(String). (optional)
 		
 	Other Plugins are constructed, dependencies evaluated, etc.
 	If your dependencies are not available (ie. not installed, threw an exception during their
	initialization, etc), your Plugin's #dispose() will be called and then your Plugin
	instance will be discarded.
	Your Plugin's #init() method is called (when its dependencies are met).
 		
 			Call PluginTool#getService(Class) to get service
 			implementations. (the service class being requested should already be
 			listed in the @PluginInfo)
 			Create Actions (optional)
 			Other initialization stuff.
 		
	Your Plugin's #readConfigState(SaveState) is called.
 	...user uses Ghidra...
 		
 			Your Plugin's #processEvent(PluginEvent) is called for events.
 			Your Plugin's Action's methods (ie.
 			DockingAction#actionPerformed(docking.ActionContext)) are called.
 			Your Plugin's published service methods are called by other Plugins.
 			Your Plugin's listener methods are called.
 		
 	Plugin is unloaded due to shutdown of the Tool or being disabled by user
 		
			Your Plugin's #writeConfigState(SaveState) is called - override this
			method to write configuration info into the Tool definition.
 			Your Plugin's #dispose() is called - override this method to free
 			any resources and perform any needed cleanup.
 			Your Plugin's services and events are de-registered automatically.
 		
 

 Plugin Service dependency
 All Plugins must be tagged with a PluginInfo annotation.
 
 The annotation gives you the ability to declare a dependency on another Plugin
 via the PluginInfo#servicesRequired() /
 PluginInfo#servicesUsed()
 
 Ghidra will ensure that your Plugin will not be #init() until all
 of its required services are loaded successfully and are available for use when your Plugin
 calls the PluginTool#getService(Class) method.
 
 Conversely, any services your Plugin advertises in PluginInfo must be published via calls to
 #registerServiceProvided(Class, Object) in your Plugin's constructor.
 
 Cyclic dependencies are not allowed and will cause the Plugin management code to fail to load
 your Plugin. (ie. PluginA requires a service that PluginB provides, which requires a service
 that PluginA provides)

 Plugin Service implementation
 A Plugin may provide a service to other Plugins by advertising in its PluginInfo
 annotation that it PluginInfo#servicesProvided() an interface class.
 
 Your Plugin can either directly implement the interface in your Plugin class:
 
 public class MyPlugin extends Plugin implements MyService {....}
 
 or it may delegate the handling of the service interface to another object during its
 constructor:
 
 public MyPlugin(PluginTool tool) {
 ...
 MyService serviceObj = new MyService() { ... };
 registerServiceProvided(MyService.class, serviceObj);
 }
 
 When your Plugin directly implements the advertised service interface, you should not
 call #registerServiceProvided(Class, Object) for that service
 interface.
 
 Service interface classes are just normal java interface declarations and have no
 preconditions or other requirements to be used as a Plugin's advertised service interface.
 
 Optionally, service interface classes can be marked with meta-data via a
 ServiceInfo annotation that can have a
 ServiceInfo#defaultProvider() property which specifies a Plugin's
 class (or classname) that should be auto-loaded to provide an implementation of the service
 interface when that service is required by some other Plugin.  Without the defaultProvider
 information, dependent Plugins will fail to load unless the user manually loads a Plugin
 that provides the necessary interface service.
 
 Multiple Plugins can implement the same service interface.  Plugins that use that
 multi-implemented service will either receive a randomly picked instance if using
 PluginTool#getService(Class) or will receive all implementations if using
 PluginTool#getServices(Class).
 

 Plugin Events
 
 	Every type of plugin event should be represented by some class extending PluginEvent.
  One PluginEvent subclass may be used for more than one event type as long as there's some natural grouping.
 

 Component Providers
 
  A plugin may supply a ComponentProvider that provides a visual component when the plugin is added to the tool.
  TODO - needs more
 

 Important interfaces Plugins often need to implement
 
 	OptionsChangeListener - to receive notification when a configuration option
 	is changed by the user.
 	FrontEndable - marks this Plugin as being suitable for inclusion in the FrontEnd tool.
 	FrontEndOnly - marks this Plugin as FrontEnd only, not usable in CodeBrowser or other tools.
 	ProgramaticUseOnly - marks this Plugin as special and not for user configuration.
 	TODO

fields.javadoc: The {@link PluginTool} that hosts/contains this Plugin.
fields.name: tool
fields.comment: The PluginTool that hosts/contains this Plugin.

fields.javadoc: Name of this plugin, derived from the simple class name.
fields.name: name
fields.comment: Name of this plugin, derived from the simple class name.

fields.javadoc: Static information about this Plugin, derived from its {@link PluginInfo} annotation.
fields.name: pluginDescription
fields.comment: Static information about this Plugin, derived from its PluginInfo annotation.

fields.javadoc:
Temporary compatibility for Plugins that have not been updated to new PluginInfo API.

Contains the list of service classes that this plugin registered as being required.

Ignored if the PluginDescription has values for requiredServices.
fields.name: legacyRequiredServices
fields.comment:
Temporary compatibility for Plugins that have not been updated to new PluginInfo API.
 
 Contains the list of service classes that this plugin registered as being required.
 
 Ignored if the PluginDescription has values for requiredServices.

fields.javadoc:
Flag that indicates that this Plugin's constructor phase has finished.  Used to
 decide if events or services should be directly registered with the Tool or if they
 should be queued to be registered later.
fields.name: constructorFinished
fields.comment:
Flag that indicates that this Plugin's constructor phase has finished.  Used to
 decide if events or services should be directly registered with the Tool or if they
 should be queued to be registered later.
